body: It would help if you showed the `curl -V` output of the curl versions as it shows details about what you've used.

Thanks for the quick reply, here it is:
```
curl 8.16.0-rc1 (x86_64-pc-linux-gnu) libcurl/8.16.0-rc1 OpenSSL/3.5.1 zlib/1.3.1 brotli/1.1.0 zstd/1.5.7 libidn2/2.3.8 libpsl/0.21.2 libssh2/1.11.1 nghttp2/1.64.0 nghttp3/1.8.0 librtmp/2.3 OpenLDAP/2.6.10
Release-Date: 2025-08-18, security patched: 8.16.0~rc1-1~exp1
Protocols: dict file ftp ftps gopher gophers http https imap imaps ipfs ipns ldap ldaps mqtt pop3 pop3s rtmp rtsp scp sftp smb smbs smtp smtps telnet tftp ws wss
Features: alt-svc AsynchDNS brotli GSS-API HSTS HTTP2 HTTP3 HTTPS-proxy HTTPSRR IDN IPv6 Kerberos Largefile libz NTLM PSL SPNEGO SSL SSLS-EXPORT threadsafe TLS-SRP UnixSockets zstd

```
Thanks, this shows OpenSSL-QUIC used as the HTTP/3 backend.
Seems to work with Nghttp3+Ngtcp2+OpenSSL instead.

It seems that *sometimes* this works and most often not. Possibly due to some round-robin thing in Google's end. In my tests I could make it work with `--resolve www.google.com:443:216.58.209.164` and fail with `--resolve www.google.com:443:142.250.74.142`

rename.to: --http3-only doesn't work on https://www.google.com/ with OpenSSL-QUIC

body:
I did some preliminary wiresharking, and in the problematic case we can see that the HTTP/3 request is never actually sent so it ends up just a QUIC connection that gets a ping sent over it every 15 seconds to stay alive until the server gets bored after a few minutes and kills it.

The request is sent off from curl code but never ends up on the wire. Need more digging.

When I add more `-vvvv` flags to increase logging, the problem seems less likely to trigger which could indicate that timing is involved.

I'm not likely to work more on this issue personally in the near term. I feel I have more important matters to spend my time on.

This problem is *likely* specific to the OpenSSL-QUIC implementation or libcurl's use of its API. This backend is experimental and we recommend using the ngtcp2 backend instead, which does not reproduce this problem.

A challenge with debugging this problem is the timing sensitivity or if it is network package ordering or similar. Adding delays seems to make it work. It is also complicated as it seems to only trigger with some of Google's servers, not all.

@FabioPedretti We will soon change curl on Debian to use the ngctp2 backend in case this is a problem for you. I will also make sure it gets to stable-backports for stable users, this should all happen within the next weeks.

@bagder and everyone else, thanks for looking into this.

@samueloph it is not that it is a specific problem for me, I just noticed it as  a prominent feature of Debian 13 (as reported at https://www.debian.org/releases/trixie/release-notes/whats-new.en.html#wcurl-and-http-3-support-in-curl), tried it and noticed the issue. It is a good idea to use a different backend if it can fix the issue, thanks.

repository.name: curl
repository.description: A command line tool and library for transferring data with URL syntax, supporting DICT, FILE, FTP, FTPS, GOPHER, GOPHERS, HTTP, HTTPS, IMAP, IMAPS, LDAP, LDAPS, MQTT, POP3, POP3S, RTMP, RTMPS, RTSP, SCP, SFTP, SMB, SMBS, SMTP, SMTPS, TELNET, TFTP, WS and WSS. libcurl offers a myriad of powerful features

body:
Update:
- I noticed `openssl 3.6.0-1` in Debian experimental, tried it with `curl 8.16.0-1` -> the issue is still reproducible;
- I also noticed `curl 8.16.0-2` in Debian sid with the changelog `Build OpenSSL HTTP/3 support with ngtcp2`, installed it into Debian testing -> now I am getting this other issue:
```
# curl -v --http3-only -s -S https://www.google.com/ 
* Host www.google.com:443 was resolved.
* IPv6: 2a00:1450:4002:809::2004
* IPv4: 142.250.180.132
*   Trying [2a00:1450:4002:809::2004]:443...
* Immediate connect fail for 2a00:1450:4002:809::2004: La rete non  raggiungibile
*   Trying 142.250.180.132:443...
*  CAfile: /etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt
*  CApath: /etc/ssl/certs
nghttp3_settings.c:93 nghttp3_settingslen_version: Unreachable.
Annullato                  curl -v --http3-only -s -S https://www.google.com/

```

Note: I also installed `libnghttp3-9 1.12.0-1` from sid (before it was `1.11.0-1`) and now curl with http3 on Google finally works fine!

@samueloph Maybe `curl` Debian package should depends on `libnghttp3-9 >= 1.12.0-1~`? https://salsa.debian.org/debian/curl/-/blob/debian/unstable/debian/control?ref_type=heads#L30

Thank you for the confirmation @FabioPedretti.

Starting with curl `8.16.0-2`, HTTP/3 support is provided with ngtcp2 instead of OpenSSL-QUIC.

I've fixed the version requirements for the curl package in Unstable and I'll upload it to Stable-Backports in roughly 5 days from now, once the package migrates to Testing, but then it will spend a few days in the backports NEW queue until it's accepted.

I'll comment back on this issue once it reaches Stable-Backports.
